introduction.p: In each of the following problems, determine the total force exerted by water against the surface that is described.

statement.p: Consider a rectangular dam that is 100 feet wide and 50 feet tall, and suppose that water presses against the dam all the way to the top.

hint.p: Put the center of the top of the dam at the origin and let the positive x-axis point down.

solution.p:
We let the positive x-axis point down and let x be the distance from the top of the dam. The area of a typical horizontal slice (in square feet) is
A_{\text{ slice } } = 100 \Delta x . The pressure (in pounds per square foot) at depth x is given by P_{\text{ slice } } = 62.5 x. So the force on a typical slice (in pounds) is
F_{\text{ slice } } = (62.4x)(100 \Delta x) = 6240 x \Delta x . So the force of the water against the dam is
F = \int_{x = 0}^{x=50} (6240 x) dx = 7~800~000 \text{ pounds } .

statement.p: Consider a semicircular dam with a radius of 30 feet. Suppose that the water rises to within 10 feet of the top of the dam.

hint.p: With the positive x-axis pointing down, the equation for the edge of the semi-circular dam is y = \sqrt{900-x^2}.

solution.p:
We let the positive x-axis point down and let x be the distance from the top of the dam. We place the top of the dam along the x-axis with the center at the origin. So the equation for the semicircle is y = \sqrt{30^2 - x^2} = \sqrt{900 - x^2}. The area of a typical horizontal slice (in square feet) is
A_{\text{ slice } } = 2y \Delta x = 2 \sqrt{900 - x^2} \Delta x . At a given value of x, the depth of the water is (x - 10). So the pressure (in pounds per square foot) at x is given by P_{\text{ slice } } = 62.4 (x - 10). So the force on a typical slice (in pounds) is
F_{\text{ slice } } = 62.4(x - 10) \left(2 \sqrt{900 - x^2} \Delta x \right) = 124.8 (x - 10)\sqrt{900 - x^2} \Delta x . So the force of the water against the dam is
F = \int_{x=10}^{x=30} 124.8 (x - 10)\sqrt{900 - x^2} dx = 426~488 \text{ pounds } .

statement.p: Consider a trough with triangular ends, as pictured in the following figure where the tank is 10 feet long, the top is 5 feet wide, and the tank is 4 feet deep. Say that the trough is full to within 1 foot of the top with water of weight density 62.4 pounds/ft^3. How much force does the water exert against one of the triangular ends?

hint.p: The equation for the line that bounds the right side of the trough is y = -\frac{5}{8}x + 2.5 .

solution.p:
We let the positive x-axis point down and let x be the distance from the top of the dam. We place the top of the trough along the x-axis with the center at the origin. We need the equation for the straight line from the point (0, 2.5) to the point (4, 0). The equation for this line is y = -\frac{5}{8}x + 2.5 = 2.5 - 0.625x. The area of a typical horizontal slice (in square feet) is
A_{\text{ slice } } = 2y \Delta x = 2(2.5 - 0.625x) \Delta x = (5 - 1.25x) \Delta x . At a given value of x, the depth of the water is (x - 1). So the pressure (in pounds per square foot) at x is given by P_{\text{ slice } } = 62.4 (x - 1). So the force on a typical slice (in pounds) is
F_{\text{ slice } } = 62.4(x - 1) \left( 5 - 1.25x \Delta x \right) = 62.4 (x - 1)(5 - 1.25x) \Delta x . So the force of the water against the trough is
F = \int_{x=1}^{x=4} 62.4 (x - 1)(5 - 1.25x) dx = 351 \text{ pounds } .
